In addition to counting the votes, candidates are paying attention to a different number - the number of delegates they walk away with.
Here to spell it all out for us is NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
Hey, Ron.
Good to be with you, Farai.
So, let's get down to the basics.
What the heck are delegates?
Why do they even matter?

The delegates are the people who are actually going to go to the Democratic convention in Denver at the end of August, and to the Republican convention in the Twin Cities of Minnesota in the beginning of September.
These are going to be back-to-back events.

And the delegates at these two conventions will have a party - you know, four nights on national television - and they will also get down to the business of actually nominating the Democratic and Republican candidates for president.

So everything else that goes on January, February and March, all these events - primaries, caucuses, conventions, all that - leads up to choosing the people who will go to those two cities and do the actual voting to choose the nominees.
So how do these folks get chosen?
I'm assuming it has something to do with elections?
Yes, it does.
You have to volunteer and you have to file with the party and you submit a petition and so forth, then you sign your name and you want to be a delegate.
You also get associated with a party because the delegates are not just with the party but with the candidate, because the delegates are not only going to be a Democrat or a Republican.
They're going to be, for example, a Hillary Clinton Democrat or a Mitt Romney Republican.

So, they're then going to be allocated when the votes come in from each party's primary or caucus according to how well the candidate did, and the rules are quite different from state to state and from party to party.

The biggest difference being that the Democrats always try to make the results of their elections and primaries and caucuses as proportional as possible, splitting the delegates as close to the ratio or fraction of the actual popular vote that each candidate got.
The Republicans use the system a little differently.

They try to winnow it all down to getting a candidate as quickly as possible by making a lot of their states winner-take-all, which means if you win by one vote or plurality in a given state, you take home all the delegates from that state, bang right there.
Now, if we talk about Nevada, you had a situation where Senator Clinton got more of the popular vote, but Senator Obama got more of the delegates.
How did something like that happen?
Well, the Democrats have several different kinds of delegates.
That includes, for example, what are called superdelegates.
That's about a fifth of the total Democratic convention.
And they are people who are already delegates by virtue of their office.

As, say, to the president of the United States, if he's a Democrat; vice president of the United States, if he's a Democrat - they're automatically delegates to the Democratic convention - former presidents; members of Congress; governors; members of the Democratic National Committee.
So that's the first category.
The next category are the people who are allocated on the basis of these primaries and caucuses that we're having.
And they split into a couple of different kinds as well.
For example, there are some that are chosen statewide and it's proportional by the results statewide.
So if candidate X and candidate Y split the state vote pretty much 60-40, then candidate X gets 60 percent of the statewide delegates and candidate Y gets the other 40 percent.
Then, there are a third group which are chosen - who are chosen district by district.
And when I say district, I usually mean a congressional district, a district that elects a member of Congress.
But in some of the smallest states where they only have one seat in Congress, they do it by legislative districts from their state legislature.
And in each district, there is an allocated number of delegates.
It might be two or three.
It might be as many as six or seven.
And that allocation, then, is awarded on the basis of how the vote went just in that one district.
I'll be honest with you.
This sounds extremely complicated.
How did we get to a situation like this?
I understand it has something to do with the framing of the Constitution.
But how did we get this situation?
It's actually democracy in action, if you want to call it that.
I mean, the parties are in charge here.
It's related to the Constitution.
It's related to the electoral system in general.
But it also has to do with each party pursuing its own ends.

And after 1972, where there was a major fracas at the Democratic National Convention over whether or not they were going to seat the California delegates all for George McGovern - in other words, unit rule, winner-take all - or, whether they were going to split them proportionally among the several candidates who were running in California that year.
And after that big fight, they finally decided, look, we're not going to have any more winner-take-all here in the Democratic Party.
We're going to make this as democratic - small D - as we possibly can.
We're going to break it down, not only by the statewide proportion of the vote, but also district by district.
We're really going to get down into the grassroots here and make each individual Democrats - large D, now - feel as though he or she is really making his or her vote count.
What about independents and third parties?
You know, there have been some notable runs - Ralph Nader, Ross Perot.
And how does our system account or not account for people who were outside - of candidates who were outside of the two major political parties?

Now you are getting back into the Constitution, Farai, because in the Constitution, all it says is that there will be candidates for president and that the electoral college will decide who actually has won the presidential election.
It does not contemplate political parties.
It does not assume that there would be Democrats or Republicans or Whigs or anybody else.

So once we get outside the realm of the two major parties that have dominated our politics since the Civil War, once we get outside of that into independent land or third party or fourth party or fifth party, they can either have a convention, or an individual candidate, say, a Mike Bloomberg, with pretty much limitless personal resources, the mayor of New York.
He can go out and get on ballots on his own all around the country.
And in fact, he started to do that in places like Texas, where they have really early filing deadlines.

So, it sounds like, what you're saying, is that the two political parties, the two major political parties, have reshaped over time how they choose these representatives which then choose their representative for the race.
How has this movement by the political parties set them up differently?
You mentioned a little bit about the winner-take-all system versus proportionality.
What are these parties trying to do if you can kind of think in the form of a large institution?
Yes.
Well, if you go back a generation or two, both parties pretty much chose their presidential candidates in what was often referred to as the smoke-filled room.

In other words, you would go to the convention, there would be several people who wanted the job, they would be campaigning in a variety of ways, and they would have some delegates who they consider to be their delegates because there had been a few primaries.
And there were a few primaries in certain states that go way back in our history through the 20th century - Oregon, Wisconsin, a few others.

And these people would then get to the convention - some of them pledged, some of them not pledged, most of them people who were party professionals or already office holders - and they would kind of get together at some point or another in some backroom and decide which one of the presidential candidates would be strongest.
And that person, eventually, after several ballots, would get the nod.
Back a couple of generations ago, that's what both parties did.

But then, increasingly, the Democrats, then followed by the Republicans, started having more and more primaries and requiring the delegates to the convention to be chosen by primaries or caucuses and have a much more direct connection to the popular vote, to the people, to the members of the party and to independents as well who took part in the primaries.
And that made both party's much more democratic operations - again, small D.
But the Democrats - large D, capital D - pushed it a lot further than the Republicans.
The Republicans want to restrain the representational nature of the system a little bit so as to reach a conclusion a little faster.
And that's the big difference now.
I think in Super Tuesday-voting today, for example, it's quite possible that one Republican candidate will get enough votes around the country that he'll become the nominee more or less de facto.
On the Democratic side, though, there's really no chance to that.
